--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>

> > Second, =
genes NEAT genomes are actually ordered from oldest to newest
> > gene, whi=
ch makes singlepoint crossover have a strange meaning:  It
> > means, in ef=
fect, take all the older genes from one parent and all the
> > newer genes =
from the other and concatenate them.  Intuitively I don't
> > see a really =
useful reason to do that.
> 
> Might that be one reason why it works so poo=
rly? If you think of a
P-NEAT
> substrate for a checkers board evaluation, =
maybe it would be better
to take
> contiguous regions instead of ordering b=
ased on age.
> 
> It would be an interesting area for someone to conduct re=
search.
> 
> Thanks again for clarifying these issues.
>

Yes I agree that =
the historical ordering of genes might be the reason
singlepoint crossover =
works poorly.  There may be more sophisticated
orderings as you point out. =
 However, since uniform crossover works
fine and I don't think of sets of c=
ontiguous genes in NEAT as modules
anyway, I would not expect that it would=
 be much better than uniform
crossover.

ken
